In Julia, Write a function `ispersonal` that returns a trait if the provided Vehicle type is a personal vehicle for everyday driving. All vehicles are subtypes of AbstractVehicle. Function must work for types: Car, Motorcycle, Bus, Truck. The first two should return true, the latter two should return false . The function should default to false for any other subtype of AbstractVehicle. Provide an example.

Certainly! Here is a possible implementation of the `ispersonal` function in Julia:
```
module Traits

export ispersonal

const AbstractVehicle = Union{Car, Motorcycle, Bus, Truck}

function ispersonal(vehicle::AbstractVehicle)
    # Check if vehicle is a personal vehicle for everyday driving
    return vehicle === Car || vehicle === Motorcycle
end

# Examples
println("Is a personal car?") && ispersonal(Car) # true
println("Is a personal motorcycle?") && ispersonal(Motorcycle) # true
println("Is a bus for transporting people?") && ispersonal(Bus) # false
println("Is a truck for transporting goods?") && ispersonal(Truck) # false
```
In this implementation, the `ispersonal` function takes an `AbstractVehicle` object as input and returns `true` if it is a personal vehicle (i.e., a car or motorcycle), and `false` otherwise. The function uses type inference to determine the type of the input `vehicle`, and then checks whether it matches one of the two personal vehicle types (`Car` or `Motorcycle`).

The function also includes some example calls to demonstrate how to use it. For instance, calling `ispersonal(Car)` will return `true`, as a car is a personal vehicle for everyday driving. Similarly, calling `ispersonal(Motorcycle)` will also return `true`. On the other hand, calling `ispersonal(Bus)` or `ispersonal(Truck)` will both return `false`, as those are not personal vehicles.

Note that this implementation assumes that a personal vehicle is defined as one used for everyday driving, and may not be applicable in all contexts or cultures. Additionally, the definition of a "personal" vehicle may vary depending on local laws, regulations, or cultural norms.
